context.introduction: Elevate your Italian cooking mastery! Learn the traditional techniques of fresh pasta making, risotto perfection, and the foundational sauces that have made Italian cuisine beloved worldwide.

sections.title: Sfoglia: The Art of Fresh Pasta
sections.content: Sfoglia is the Italian technique for rolling pasta dough into thin, silky sheets. Traditional sfoglia uses only eggs and '00' flour, kneaded until smooth and elastic, then rolled paper-thin. The dough should be transparent enough to read through when properly executed. This technique creates the base for tortellini, lasagna, and countless regional specialties.

sections.title: Risotto: The Perfect Marriage
sections.content: Authentic risotto requires dry white wine (Pinot Grigio or Sauvignon Blanc) to deglaze the rice and add acidity that balances the creaminess. The wine is added after toasting the rice and must be fully absorbed before adding warm broth. This step develops the complex flavor foundation that makes risotto extraordinary.

sections.title: The Constant Stirring Technique
sections.content: Risotto must be stirred constantly with a wooden spoon in one direction to release the rice's starches gradually. This creates the characteristic creamy texture without cream. The stirring motion should be gentle but continuous, ensuring even cooking and preventing the rice from sticking to the pan bottom.

sections.title: Soffritto: The Flavor Foundation
sections.content: Soffritto is the slow-cooking method that forms the base of countless Italian sauces and stews. The holy trinity of onions, carrots, and celery is finely diced and cooked slowly in olive oil until soft and fragrant. This technique concentrates flavors and creates the aromatic foundation that defines authentic Italian cooking.

sections.title: Intermediate Mastery
listItems: Rest pasta dough for 30 minutes before rolling for better elasticity
Keep risotto broth warm in a separate pan throughout cooking
Add wine to risotto when you hear the rice 'singing' (slight sizzling)
Soffritto vegetables should be translucent, never browned
Taste and adjust seasoning constantly during the cooking process
